Title: Meghan Trainor Quit a Bad Habit Because of a Psychic's Message
Description:
Meghan Trainor recently revealed that a health scare led to her 60-pound weight loss. Now, she's admitted that she quit a bad habit because a psychic had a dire message for the star.

“The psychic never met me,” Trainor told People. “My husband [Daryl Sabara] was gifted a session with her and she said, ‘Your wife is … non-stop [when it comes to drinking coffee] and it's not helping her and she's just crashing out.'”

“I was like, ‘How does she know that?' And he came home and told me, and I immediately stopped,” the singer revealed. “Cold turkey just stopped because I was drinking it all day to just survive and be steady and then I would crash and be buzzing at night to sleep.”

Noting that her “adrenals were shot” and her hormones were “so off,” Trainor also told People, “I wasn't feeling great. And I was like, ‘I don't understand. I eat so healthy, I work out. Why do I feel like this?' And I realized I was overworking myself.”

While quitting resulted in a “tough week” for Trainor, she explained that she now has “more energy than ever.”

She added, “It was life-changing.”

Trainor is set to launch a tour in June 2026, and intends to tackle it in the same way she has in the past, telling People, “No sleep, power through and thrive.”

“We get up at 7 a.m. because the kids get up at 7 a.m. and then we go find an amusement park or a museum. They love children's museums… then we eat lunch together, I do a soundcheck, we have early dinner so that I don't burp on stage,” she said of the family's time on the road.

“And after soundcheck, I'm in full glam, like pop star outfit, and I'm helping our incredible nanny Leslie, who helps us out and my husband and my mom,” she added. “There's four of us on two kids trying to get them in a bath that we unfold to put in this shower. It's chaos.”

Trainor continued by saying, “Then once they're good to go, we walk them to the bus and they go to bed. And then I do the show and I get to sleep at about 11 or midnight. And then we get up and it's Groundhog Day and we do it all over again.”

Title: Jennifer Aniston & Beau Step Out in Coordinating Cuteness
Description:
On Saturday Nov. 29, beloved actress Jennifer Aniston and her man, wellness entrepreneur and hypnotherapist Jim Curtis, stepped out in cozy yet stylish winter wear in New York City. Following a holiday weekend brunch at Cafe Cluny in the West Village, People snapped a few shots of the pair braving the chilly temperatures. 

An onlooker told People that they “smiled and looked very happy” during their NYC afternoon. Since Aniston hard-launched their relationship via Instagram on Nov 2 on his 50th birthday, this is their first major holiday spent together. And with Christmas just around the corner, this next month is sure to be memorable!  

The two first sparked dating rumors way back in May of 2025 when she included a photo of Curtis's book, “Shift,” in an Instagram carousel. Page Six then caught them canoodling on a swanky yacht in Mallorca, and snapped shots of them holding hands and leaning close to one another. Following their vacation, they enjoyed a lengthy dinner date with Jason Bateman and Amanda Anka, further fueling speculation. And then… Aniston's Instagram confirmation. 

Two days later, Curtis included Aniston in one of his posts and the rest, as they say, is history. Or, in this case, just beginning. 

Aniston and Curtis recently made their first official appearance as lovebirds at ELLE's Women in Hollywood event on Nov. 17 in Beverly Hills. She was honored at the soiree and when her pal Adam Sandler introduced her, he gushed over both his friend and her new beau. “When we are around you, me and [wife] Jackie Sandler are so happy you and Jim found each other and are having the love affair you two deserve. We love you, Jim. The whole world loves you.”

Those are certainly some powerful words for a friend's boyfriend, but if they're any indication of the happiness he's brought into her life, then safe to say that fans echo Sandler's same sentiment! 

Whether viewers remember Aniston from “Friends,” or know her for her latest turn on “The Morning Show,” or are anxiously awaiting her juicy upcoming role in the TV adaptation of Jennette McCurdy's memoir, “I'm Glad My Mom Died,” we're all optimistically rooting for them.   





I have to say this is a match made by god, to the both of yous, right on, and bless you both for the rest of your days, right on,much love and respect and blessings!

Title: ‘The Voice' Playoffs Week 1 Live Recap & Spoilers
Description:
Time for the Playoffs on “The Voice” season 28 tonight on NBC. We have the first eight artists singing for their coaches — Reba McEntire, Michael Bublé, Niall Horan, and Snoop Dogg — to earn a spot in the Live Finale in two weeks on “The Voice” 2025. Viewers will get their first chance to vote for their favorite artists on “The Voice” 2025.  Who moves on and who is eliminated on “The Voice” tonight? Watch with us during our “The Voice” season 28 live recap below and find out with us.

We kick things off with the Playoffs on “The Voice” season 28 tonight. There are 16 artists remaining on this season, and tonight we get to see half of them take the stage for a shot at a spot in the Voice Finale in two weeks. For tonight, it will be Team Reba and Team Bublé performing for their coaches, with one spot for each team open in the Voice Finale. Then it goes to America to vote, so watch with us to see who stays and who goes home. Find out with us during our Live Recap below!

WARNING: SPOILERS AHEAD: THIS LIVE RECAP WILL BE UPDATED THROUGHOUT THE EPISODE, SO DO NOT KEEP READING IF YOU DO NOT WANT TO READ SPOILERS.

KEEP REFRESHING THE PAGE FOR THE LATEST “THE VOICE” LIVE RECAP UPDATES.

Time for the Playoffs to begin. Team Reba and Team Bublé will be performing tonight. Each coach gets to pick one artist to represent them in the Live Finale in two weeks.

At the end of the show, voting opens for the first time this season. America will get to vote to send one of the non-selected artists from tonight to also make the Live Finale, so three artists total from tonight will make the Voice Finale!

Aaron is definitely missing his family during this process. This is also Reba's Mic Drop selection. For this performance, he is singing “Beer Never Broke My Heart” by Luke Combs. He said it's a fun, upbeat song, and he wants to show that before the finale.

Aaron is definitely country. He has such a strong voice. It works well on this song, and he got the crowd behind him.

Coaches' Feedback: Snoop said he performs like a superstar. You can't lose with him. Reba said he did wonderful in rehearsal, but this is the cherry on top.

Michael said she is the best vocalist that he's ever seen on “The Voice. For this performance, she is singing “Don't Stop Believin'” by Journey. She said she chose this song, as it is the anthem to her life, and never stop believing. 

Oh my, Jazz did her thing on this song. This is a song everyone knows. However, she put her own twist on it. Those notes she was hitting were crazy. This was a stellar performance.

Coaches' Feedback: Niall said there is zero she can't do. She is a ridiculous singer, and she deserves to be in the finale. Michael said he got goosebumps; that was amazing.

This rocker is the Carson Callback. For the Playoffs, he is singing “Undressed” by Sombr. He is hoping to go from almost being sent home to the Finale.

He has a low-key voice. It's just subtle, but it works for this song. It's a cool tune, and I think he sounds good on it. He hits a long, big note towards the end. Ryan has a good vibe, and it works with this song.

Coaches' Feedback: Niall said it felt like we were at his show. Reba said he keeps giving more, and she loves what he's bringing to the show.

Michael said she can sing any genre. Reba tried to steal her from Team Bublé. For the Playoffs, Trinity said she can dive into a different side: rock. She is singing “Barracuda” by Heart.

Yes, this is a different side for her. She has a very strong voice. However, this song choice doesn't work for me. I think she could shine on something else, and this just fell flat for me.

Coaches' Feedback: Snoop said she was up there rocking out, and she just moved up in my book. Michael said she is so quiet in real life, but she has so much confidence as an artist. She has all the elements it takes to be a real star.

Aubrey is another one-chair turn. Niall said she is a black horse in this competition. For the Playoffs, Aubrey will be singing “Black Velvet” by Alannah Myles. Reba said this is not a sweet song she has been singing, so she needs to bring the attitude.

She has that country twang to her, and it works on this song. Her voice is so pure, and it has this sound to it that is appealing. Such a good tone, and I am a fan.

Coaches' Feedback: Niall said those last two performances by her deserve a spot in the finale. She is special. Reba said she loves the song, and she stepped out on this stage, and she owned it. She sang her butt off, and she has great stage appeal. She is the complete package.

Rob auditioned for “The Voice” during season 25, but got no chairs to turn around. Now, here he is, just one step away from the Voice Finale. For the Playoffs, he is singing “I Hope You Dance” by Lee Ann Womack.

I feel Rob has a very good voice. He seems like a very seasoned singer, but this song choice is just mellow to me. It starts too slowly for me. He finally kicks in right towards the end, and hits a big note, and it works for me. You can feel the emotion at the end.

Coaches' Feedback: Reba said it touched her heart. He took that song and made it better. Snoop said he is sweet on him and would take him into the studio and record with him.

Reba said Peyton is his chamillione, and she is surprised by him every time he takes the stage. Before this, he was gigging full-time and singing on small stages; now he is so close to the Voice Finale. For the Playoffs, he is singing “Hold Back the River” by James Bay.

You want a person to have that something. Something in their voice that just stands out, makes you feel something. I feel like Peyton has that. His voice is unique, and I enjoy listening to him sing.

Coaches' Feedback: Snoop said he would be smokin' and vibin' to his music. Reba said he is so proud of him, and everyone around the world can see how good he is.

Michael said Max is his 14-year-old phenom. Max was Michael's Mic Drop pick also. For this Playoff, he will be singing “A Change Is Gonna Come” by Sam Cooke. He said he is going to sing it for his family and for the world.

It's just amazing how he is only 14 years old. His voice is so strong and old school. He is so confident on that stage for someone in high school! Max is a winner, and this is going to be a tough one for Michael.

Coaches' Feedback: Snoop said Michael, that is the winner of “The Voice.” Michael said he can be so quiet, but he steps up, and people listen. He could not have asked for him to be better.

Reba and Michael had time to make their decision. Here are the results and who they picked to move on to the Voice Finale in two weeks:

Now it is time for America to vote. You can go here to vote for one of the following artists to move on to the Voice Finale. Voting is open until 7:00 a.m. ET on December 2:

Only one of those six artists can make it through to the finale. Who are you voting for?

Voting for Aaron or Payton.
The two judges did not pick the best singers to be finalists tonight! Hope the audiance makes a better choice!

I've liked Aaron from the beginning, but last night was not his best performance. I liked Peyton and Ryan.

Title: The Latest Gwen Stefani & Blake Shelton Romance Update
Description:
Gwen Stefani and Blake Shelton kept their holiday low-key at home and shared a sweet moment with fans. On November 28, Stefani posted an Instagram Stories photo of Shelton kissing her on the cheek as she smiled in a flannel.

There was no caption or explanation, but the picture gave a quiet update on where things stand for the former coaches on “The Voice.” It was a relaxed look at their post-Thanksgiving weekend and a reminder that they're spending the season together.

A source told E! News that the couple planned to spend the holidays in Oklahoma with their family, keeping things “lowkey” after a busy year of music, TV projects, and business ventures.

Stefani and Shelton, who married in 2021, have been laying low in recent weeks. According to E! News, the couple skipped the Country Music Awards on November 19, with an insider sharing that they would be “watching the CMAs on their TV this year” instead of attending in person.

The decision aligns with how Shelton has described their life in Oklahoma. In a 2023 interview with E! News, he shared that their Southern property has helped Stefani tap into a new side of herself.

“I'm not going to say that she's become this country girl, but I just think we're starting to see a different side of Gwen,” Shelton said.

Stefani has echoed that sentiment. Speaking to The Guardian in 2023, she explained that their shared time on the land—especially during the pandemic—became a meaningful part of their relationship.

“I know this sounds weird, but Blake and I came together in gardening,” Stefani said. “We have a house together in Oklahoma, and during the pandemic, we came across this very old building on the land, and there were some purple irises, which someone must have planted centuries ago, but they've survived.”

She added that meeting Shelton after her divorce from Gavin Rossdale felt transformative. “Meeting my husband felt like a second chance at life,” she said. “Because when my family fell apart, it felt like a catastrophe. How do you pick yourself up from that? But God put this other person there to love me.”

Shelton has also spoken about their holiday traditions in Oklahoma. In a 2023 interview with People, he joked that the house has one major Thanksgiving rule: “Never say no to any kind of food.” He said he likes to experiment with “whatever weird one we come up with,” while Stefani handles the more traditional recipes. “We go all out for Thanksgiving,” he added. “We've got a huge family, so we feel good about making a bunch of food.”

While Shelton officially stepped away from his full-time role on “The Voice” after season 23, he has not disappeared from the show's orbit. In an April 2024 interview with E! News, he explained that his exit felt like the right move.

“I did 23 seasons of the show and I enjoyed it,” he said. “And by the time I got to that last season, it was time.”

Shelton said he wanted to refocus on his country career. “I needed to get back to what my day job was anyway,” he explained. “Which is, you know, being a country singer.” He added that while he still feels close to the “Voice” family, he does not see himself returning as a full-time coach: “As far as the job goes, I don't think I'm ever ready to do that again as I sit here now.”

Even so, Shelton popped up in a playful way during a recent episode of “The Voice” season 28. When Michael Bublé joked about chasing a three-peat as a winning coach, Niall Horan responded by playing an audio clip of Shelton saying, “I don't give a crap about a three-peat.”

The moment sent the audience and coaches into laughter. Horan looked up and joked, “My father! Is that you?” before replaying the clip and adding, “I miss you dad. I know you're back there in Oklahoma, harvesting some fields or something.”

For fans, it was a reminder that even if Shelton is spending more time at home with Stefani and their blended family, his presence still looms large over the “Voice” stage—and his romance with Stefani remains firmly in the spotlight, even when they keep things quiet.

New episodes of “The Voice” season 28 air Mondays and Tuesdays at 8/7c on NBC, with episodes available to stream the next day on Peacock.

Title: Michael Buble's Wife & Family: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know
Description:
Michael Bublé is a four-time Grammy winner and longtime “The Voice” coach, but his most important role is dad. The singer and his wife, Argentine actress Luisana Lopilato, share four kids and have been married since 2011. Their love story started overseas, grew through music, and became the foundation of a very close family. Here's what you need to know.

Bublé and Lopilato first crossed paths in Buenos Aires in 2008, not long after Bublé's breakup with actress Emily Blunt.

Lopilato was already a household name in Argentina thanks to her role in “Rebelde Way” and her pop-rock group Erreway.

Bublé has said he was instantly taken with her and even wrote his hit “Haven't Met You Yet” about their relationship. She starred in the video before they were officially a couple.

They were engaged by 2009 and married twice in 2011—first in Argentina and then again in Canada.

Noah was born in 2013 and instantly changed Bublé's world. When he was diagnosed with cancer at age 3, the family put work on hold. After 18 months of treatment, Noah went into remission, per People. Bublé later said the experience reshaped everything in his life and made him see success and family differently.

Now 12, Noah is thriving and has even taken an interest in music. Bublé once shared a video of him playing piano and joked, “He has more talent in his little fingers than I have in my whole body.”

Elias was born in 2016 and is known in the family for his love of Marvel characters. Bublé once shared a birthday picture of him dressed as Captain America.

In a visit to “The View,” Bublé shared the story of telling the kids they were expecting a new baby. Elias wanted to know why he wasn't invited when “We told them, ‘You know, Mommy has a baby in her tummy and you're gonna have a little brother or sister,' and my 5-year-old Eli was just distraught,” the singer recalled. “And we said, ‘What's wrong?' and he said, ‘Why didn't you invite us to watch when you fell in love and made the baby?' “

Vida arrived in 2018. Her name means “life,” and she was named partly after both grandmothers. Bublé has shared videos of dance classes, Marvel debates, and their father-daughter routines. He once joked her first words were practically: “I am inevitable.”

Cielo was born in 2022, and Bublé has said this pregnancy was special because it would “probably be the last.” She was introduced in his music video for “I'll Never Not Love You,” where Lopilato appeared pregnant in the final scene.

Catch Michael Bublé Monday and Tuesday nights on “The Voice.”

Title: ‘Obsession' Teaser: The Next Great Horror Festival Breakout Has Arrived
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

The past decade of Hollywood horror has been dominated by names like Jordan Peele and Zach Cregger, creators who pivoted from short-form comedy careers to find massive success in genre filmmaking. In 2026, horror fans might be adding another name to that list: Curry Barker. 

Best known as one half of the “That's a Bad Idea” YouTube channel and as the director of the viral $800 short film “Milk & Serial,” Barker made his feature directorial debut with “Obsession,” a contemporary riff on a classic monkey's paw horror setup that became one of the breakout hits of the fall festival season. And a new teaser trailer offers a hint at what's in store when it opens in theaters next spring.

 








Related Stories ‘KPop Demon Hunters' Star Ken Jeong on the Magic of Making a ‘Culturally Specific' Masterpiece ‘One Battle After Another' Wins Best Film at 2025 New York Film Critics Circle Awards: Full Winners List 

Written and directed by Barker, “Obsession” stars Michael Johnston as a romantically unsuccessful young man who asks a vintage wish-granting toy to make his crush (Inde Navarrette) become obsessed with him. The rest of the cast includes Cooper Tomlinson, Megan Lawless, and Andy Richter. 

 











			Popular on IndieWire		






“Obsession” premiered in the Midnight Madness section of the 2025 Toronto International Film Festival, before making prestigious stops on the genre festival circuit like Fantastic Fest and Sitges. The film earned rave reviews from the start, prompting Focus Features to acquire it in the kind of buzzy festival deal that gets rarer and rarer with each passing year. Jason Blum also boarded the project as an executive producer through Blumhouse — arguably the biggest endorsement a new horror filmmaker can receive. 

“'Obsession' begins with the simplest of horror premises,” IndieWire's TIFF review read. “Bear is a shy and sensitive music store employee who can't find the courage to ask his co-worker and childhood friend Nikki on a date. Rather than be honest with her and tell her how he actually feels, he wanders into a woo-woo crystal store and buys a One Wish Willow, a kitschy antique toy from the 1960s that promises to grant its owner one wish when they snap a branch in half. The cashier warns him that most of the customers who buy them have complained about the results, but it wouldn't be much of a horror movie if he listened.”A Focus Features release, “Obsession” opens in theaters on May 15, 2026. Watch the film's first teaser trailer below.

Title: 'Mother Mary' Trailer: Anne Hathaway, Michaela Coel Star in Pop Epic
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

More than two years after David Lowery's new feature, “Mother Mary,” was announced, even the people involved in the film don't quite seem to know how to talk about it. But one thing that's resoundingly clear is that the hotly anticipated A24 title — which has been described as a “weird, weird film” by the “Peter Pan and Wendy” director and “transformative” by its cast — is going to be a wild ride. 

“Mother Mary” stars Anne Hathaway as a seething pop singer who becomes embroiled in a psychosexual affair with an old friend and fashion designer, played by “I May Destroy You” multi-hyphenate Michaela Coel. The trailer, which dropped Tuesday, gives audiences their first real taste of the twisted relationship between Mary (Hathaway) and Sam (Coel), who are brought back into each other's orbit by the pop singer's need for a dress that will breathe life into her comeback tour.

 











			Popular on IndieWire		




Related Stories ‘Obsession' Teaser: The Next Great Horror Festival Breakout Has Arrived ‘KPop Demon Hunters' Star Ken Jeong on the Magic of Making a ‘Culturally Specific' Masterpiece 

After being reunited, the estranged friends spend most of the film shacked up in a 13th-century barn that acts as Sam's atelier — trading violent looks over chiseled cheekbones and conjuring up old demons. As the dress comes together with the help of Sam's stone-faced assistant (Hunter Schafer), and seances are performed, a soundtrack featuring original songs by Charli XCX, Jack Antonoff, and FKA Twigs plays in the background, making for an “epic pop melodrama” with an occult flair.

 










Leading up to the trailer's release, most of what's been known about “Mother Mary” has come from its stars, who've primarily spoken about the challenging and intense experience of making it — which Lowery, for his part, has compared to shooting “Apocalypse Now.” Speaking with Vogue, Hathaway described how the film was an exercise in relinquishing control, both because she had to ad-lib the onscreen singing scenes and because she had to abandon her polished approach to performing and surrender herself to the material. 

“I had to submit to being a beginner,” she said. “The humility of that — showing up every day knowing you're going to suck. And it has to be OK. You're not ‘bad.' You're just a beginner. Getting to that mindset — I had to shed some things that were hard to shed. It was welcome. But it was hard, the way transformational experiences can be hard.” 

During a red carpet interview with IndieWire, Schafer, who makes for a haunting fashion girlie, emphasized the pleasurable aspect of the experience while still echoing her co-star's sentiments. “It was a lot of fun, and I think people are going to be mind-blown,” the “Euphoria” actor, who recently celebrated the release of “The Hunger Games: Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes,” said. “I was mind-blown.” 

 










Although as writer, director, and editor, Lowery — whose other film credits include “The Green Knight” and “The Old Man and the Gun” — was fully in control of the film, he also seems to have been disoriented by the experience. During a conversation at last year's Melbourne International Film Festival, where he spoke about taking a break from adapting stories to focus on original material, the director sounded as if he was compelled to make “Mother Mary” almost against his will. 

“I wrote the first 20 pages when I was shooting ‘Peter Pan and Wendy' and it's been percolating ever since,” Lowery said. “That movie was huge, it was one of the greatest shoots of my life and one of the hardest edits of my life and it inspired a lot of soul-searching. After that, I decided I'm just going to do something simple. I need to do a movie with just two actors in a room having a long heart-to-heart … a really gentle filmmaking experience.

“But then I thought, ‘What if one of those characters is a pop star? And what if we started at a stadium?' Then, it got bigger,” he continued. “And again, it wound up being the hardest thing I've ever done.” 

“Mother Mary” will release in April 2026 from A24. Watch the trailer below.

Title: ‘One Battle After Another' Wins 2025 Gotham Film Award for Best Feature — See the Full Winners List
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

If it's the first Monday in December (and the first day back after the Thanksgiving holiday, ouch), most of the NYC film world can be found at the Gotham Film Awards, back in its traditional venue at Cipriani Wall Street. The ceremony is typically viewed as the first big live awards show of the season, and offers a glitzy entry into the weeks (and months!) to come. As ever, IndieWire was in the room for this year's event, and watched a pretty thrilling evening unfold.

This year's nominees were led by Paul Thomas Anderson's “One Battle After Another,” which picked up six nominations, but only walked away with one: the night's crown jewel, Best Feature.

 








Related Stories ‘Obsession' Teaser: The Next Great Horror Festival Breakout Has Arrived ‘KPop Demon Hunters' Star Ken Jeong on the Magic of Making a ‘Culturally Specific' Masterpiece 

Despite an influx of tributes for other films from the studio and streaming world, including “After the Hunt,” “Springsteen: Deliver Me from Nowhere,” “Song Sung Blue,” “Frankenstein,” “Sinners,” “Hedda,” and “Jay Kelly,” it was comparatively smaller films that made off with some of the night's biggest wins. That included three wins for Jafar Panahi and his “It Was Just an Accident,” plus trophies for “My Father's Shadow,” “Pillion,” and more.

 











			Popular on IndieWire		






For the first time in its history, this year's batch of Gotham nominees included 10 Best Feature picks. In previous years, the category only included five nominees, but the category was expanded for the 2025 season to include up to 10 nominees. While Anderson's film was nominated in that category (and much was made of its studio bonafides), the other nine picks represented a strong array of indie offerings, including titles like “East of Wall,” “Lurker,” and “Familiar Touch,” alongside heavy-hitters like “Hamnet” and “Train Dreams.”

Nominees are chosen by committees of film critics, journalists, festival programmers, and film curators. Separate juries of writers, directors, actors, producers, editors, and other film industry professionals will determine the final Gothams recipients. (This year's nominating committees included myself and Chief Film Critic David Ehrlich.) 

Check out the full list of winners for this year's Gotham Film Awards below, with each winner marked in bold and with a “WINNER” next their name and/or film title.

“Bugonia” (Focus Features) — Ari Aster, Ed Guiney, Lars Knudsen, Jerry Kyoungboum Ko, Yorgos Lanthimos, Miky Lee, Andrew Lowe, Emma Stone, producers“East of Wall” (Sony Pictures Classics) — Kate Beecroft, Shannon Moss, Melanie Ramsayer, Lila Yacoub, producers“Familiar Touch” (Music Box Films) — Alexandra Byer, Sarah Friedland, Matthew Thurm, producers“Hamnet” (Focus Features) — Nicolas Gonda, Pippa Harris, Liza Marshall, Sam Mendes, Steven Spielberg, producers“If I Had Legs I'd Kick You” (A24) — Ronald Bronstein, Eli Bush, Richie Doyle, Conor Hannon, Sara Murphy, Josh Safdie, Ryan Zacarias, producers“Lurker” (Mubi) — Galen Core, Archie Madekwe, Marc Marrie, Charlie McDowell, Francesco Melzi d'Eril, Duncan Montgomery, Alex Orlovsky, Olmo Schnabel, Jack Selby, producers“One Battle After Another” (Warner Bros. Pictures) — Paul Thomas Anderson, Sara Murphy, Adam Somner, producers (WINNER)“Sorry, Baby” (A24) — Mark Ceryak, Barry Jenkins, Adele Romanski, producers“The Testament of Ann Lee” (Searchlight Pictures) — Brady Corbet, Mona Fastvold, Joshua Horsfield, Gregory Jankilevitsch, Mark Lampert, Lillian LaSalle, Andrew Morrison, Viktória Petrányi, Klaudia Smieja-Rostworowska, producers“Train Dreams” (Netflix) — Michael Heimler, Will Janowitz, Marissa McMahon, Ashley Schlaifer, Teddy Schwarzman, producers

Title: Bonnaroo 2026 Headliners: The Strokes, Skrillex, Rüfüs Du Sol, and Noah Kahan
Description:
The 2026 lineup of Bonnaroo Music & Arts Festival is here. Headlining the stalwart Tennessee festival are the Strokes, Skrillex, Rüfüs Du Sol, and Noah Kahan. A pair of special performances are also set for the Saturday night: a performance led and curated by Kesha dubbed “Superjâm Esoteríca: The Alchemy of Pop” and a “Weird Al” Yankovic show titled Bigger & Weirder Roovue. Others on the bill include Geese, Turnstile, Four Tet, Modest Mouse, Clipse, Alabama Shakes, Teddy Swims, the Neighbourhood, Role Model, Vince Staples, and Blood Orange. The festival takes place from June 11 to 14 at Bonnaroo Farm in Manchester, Tennessee. See a poster below.

Also on the bill are Griz, Japanese Breakfast, Wednesday, Wet Leg, Smino, Zack Fox, the Dare, Rachel Chinouriri, Passion Pit, Amyl and the Sniffers, Osees, Snow Strippers, Freddie Gibbs & the Alchemist, Major Lazer, Yungblud, Fcukers, Holly Humberstone, Boys Noize, Confidence Man, Lil Jon, Mt. Joy, and Yungblud, among others.

Title: Erg One / Estee Nack / BoneWeso: THE LIFE OF ERG Album Review
Description:
7.5

Genre:

Rap

Label:

23 Incredible Industries

Reviewed:

December 2, 2025

There are moments when THE LIFE OF ERG, a vibrant tape credited to a Dominican American trio from Lynn, Massachusetts, threatens to spin off its axis. “Bilderberg” begins promisingly enough, with frontman Erg One rapping calmly about favelas and Ronald Reagan over a modest drum loop; producer BoneWeso cues up a swirling violin synth. Estee Nack punches in for the hook, crooning like a gravel-voiced lounge singer, ad-libbing over his own vocal track. The instrumental drifts into the second verse, urgent horns disturbing the tranquility, rhymes drowned out in a clash of drums and street noise. It's over as soon as it arrives—the loop resets, and we're back in our lounge chairs.

These combustions add depth to Erg's landscapes, less a matter of competing visions than merging interpretations. His verses are enlivened by assured wisecracks (“Money in my hand, that bitch was a palm reader/When I asked for my flowers, they gave me an arboretum”) and tropical climes, destinations selected for unspoken business purposes. A scene veteran of two decades, Nack assumes a supervisory role, chiming in with hooks and rambling verses. The format instills balance between psychedelia and pragmatism—Erg the straight man, Nack the bellowing wild card, seasoned professionals who've lived to tell the tale.

Although compelling on its own, the intricacy warrants context. Nack cut his teeth with Tragic Allies, an operatic Lynn outfit indebted to Queensbridge lyricists Prodigy and Tragedy Khadafi. In that lineup he was kinetic and chameleonic, reciting Five Percent precepts with metronomic precision, piping choruses in melodic patois. He resurfaced, unrecognizable, in the late 2010s with variations on Roc Marciano and Westside Gunn's neoclassical raps. The whittled samples and slowed-down tempos revealed a wild-eyed preacher, allowing Nack to toy with East Coast conventions—bars veering between English and Spanish, loosely patterned rhymes landing a half-beat behind the snare.

After a stint on Gunn's Griselda Records—a nice look that reduced him to a supporting act—Nack continued tacking left with instinctive performances over deconstructed arrangements, often working in miniature. He maximizes his limited screentime on THE LIFE OF ERG, flexing a wizened, expressive flamboyance, transcending the fully-loaded bars of his Tragic Allies days. “14hrflights” finds him in conversation with himself, peppering open space with interstitial ad libs (his preferred ad lib, quixotically, is “ad lib”). He deploys an incremental technique on “Nevatrustazing,” embellishing and compounding the thesis with each sequential bar. He's always coloring outside the lines, pausing for breath where he pleases; when the couplets rhyme at all, it's usually via some slanted internal scheme.

BoneWeso spent the 2000s working in dancehall and reggaeton spaces, but you'd never know it based on THE LIFE OF ERG. His single-tracked loops are more evocative than Daringer and Nicholas Craven's, less frenetic than Conductor Williams and Don Carrera's. Erg takes cues from the instrumentals, indulging nostalgia over a dreamy sax on “Wareztheluv,” conjuring Parisian flights and top-shelf liquor on “Silenceofthelambs.” The stylistic touchstones—aspirational lifestyle raps, sampling technique, newsreels recounting drug busts and art heists—are formalities of second- or third-wave neoclassicism. What's engrossing is the trio's divergence from canon, the local idiosyncrasies and equatorial intrigue. A subtle immersion takes place; it's natural, for instance, when Nack rhymes “Tahoe” with “abajo” on “Intervention.” As in Mach-Hommy's work, the colliding dialects speak to an unlikely diaspora, secret or alternate histories of would-be Escobars in New England's rust belt.

These adaptations bestow a rich specificity, distinctive performers bending a pre-existing format for their purposes. What's difficult about the work, broadly, is a sense of contraction. There's no infrastructure for this stuff anymore; in lieu of label investment, working artists churn out project after self-released project. The environment promotes novelty, but also imposes a ceiling—the tightly plotted sagas of Mobb Deep and Capone-N-Noreaga have given way to thin margins, low stakes, narratives that never really go anywhere. Among a tidal wave of off-brand Griselda, Nack and Erg are small-city kingpins reveling in limited resources, splurging on sneakers rather than sports cars, middle-aged and flyer than they've ever been.

Title: Aya Nakamura: Destinée Album Review
Description:
6.9

Genre:

Pop/R&B

Label:

Nakamura Industrie

Reviewed:

December 2, 2025

Aya Nakamura spent the years following her 2023 album DNK embroiled in national drama that had little to do with her music. The mere suggestion that the French Malian singer might perform at the 2024 Paris Olympics ignited an ugly backlash, fueling a racist opposition campaign and a pearl-clutching debate over who ought to represent France on its biggest international stage. Nakamura sang anyway, reminding the world why she remains one of the most popular Francophone singers working today.

Destinée, her fifth album, meets the furor by leaning even harder into a sound only she can deliver. The production returns to her familiar melange of Afrobeats, zouk, pop, and R&B; features from Joé Dwèt Filé, JayO, and others add ripples of kompa, reggae, and Latin neo-soul. At 30, Nakamura sounds steelier, almost amused by her critics. In her writing, she doubles down on her signature braid of Parisian argot (slang) and Bambara, a wink to her fans and a cheeky taunt to the institutions that would prefer a more demure entertainer.

If Nakamura's third album, AYA, was “the sound of a young woman and mother who has found the love she deserves,” Destinée is that of a woman scorned. These love songs are pressure cookers, simmering with threats and accusations. Some play coy, like “Alien,” where she boasts about being insatiable, or the airy Kali Uchis collab “Baby boy,” where flirtation doubles as a power play. But on “Dis-moi,” Nakamura wonders if she's sleeping beside the devil, and Jamaican star Shenseea's warning lands like a line from a thriller: “I'll hurt you if you hurt me.”

Most compelling is how Destinée reframes Nakamura's public narrative without stooping. She doesn't sermonize about her right to belong; she treats those arguments as beneath her. Lovers, haters, and the establishment blur into a composite antagonist, a symbol of everyone who has tried to shrink her. “Blues,” a stripped-down ballad that recalls the intimacy of “Fly,” is Nakamura at her most vulnerable, voice cracking against soft keys and a heartbeat. But running beneath the album's flexes and dismissals is a deeper inquiry into power: how it's gained, lost, reclaimed, sometimes shared. She doesn't directly address the spectacle surrounding her Olympic appearance or her legal issues with her ex, but when she murmurs about numbing emotions and burying bad memories on opener “Anesthésie,” it's an easy connection to make.

For all its confidence, Destinée can rely too heavily on familiar formulas. The album stretches to 18 tracks, and many settle into a similar midtempo sway, with percussion so uniform it begins to feel automated. The hooks are sticky but predictable—you'll crave a wild solo or switch-up to jolt the hypnotic groove. Still, Nakamura stands 10 toes down in her dualities: tender and ruthless, glamorous and tired, wounded and unbothered. Destinée distills the playfulness, poise, and melodic grace that have made her a generational pop star, and with this album, she invites us to revel in the fact that she's still here.

Title: Watch the New Trailer for A24's Pop Music Movie Mother Mary
Description:
A24 has released the trailer for Mother Mary, a new film from writer and director David Lowery featuring original music by Jack Antonoff, Charli XCX, and FKA twigs. The clip introduces the pop star Mother Mary (played by Anne Hathaway) as she navigates a reunion with her former costume designer Sam Anselm (portayed by Michaela Coel). Watch the trailer below.

Antonoff, Charli XCX, and FKA twigs wrote and produced music for Mother Mary. The songs are performed in the film by Hathaway. FKA twigs also acts in Mother Mary, as do Hunter Schafer, Atheena Frizzell, Kaia Gerber, Jessica Brown Findlay, Alba Baptista, Isaura Barbé-Brown, and Sian Clifford.

This isn't the first or the last time Charli XCX has written music for an A24 film. “Hot Girl,” which she wrote with the 1975's George Daniel, appeared in the production company's 2022 murder mystery Bodies Bodies Bodies. Last month, Charli XCX shared the first teaser trailer for The Moment, the Aidan Zamiri–directed A24 movie that stars and was conceived by the pop star while touring behind Brat. (Charli XCX explained that “the seed of the idea was conceived from this idea of being pressured to make [a tour documentary]. It's fiction, but it's the realest depiction of the music industry that I've ever seen.”)

But, wait, there's more! Charli XCX recently announced her Wuthering Heights album that accompanies Emerald Fennell's upcoming film of the same name and released her John Cale collaboration “House” from that record. Plus, she's also involved in Gregg Araki's upcoming drama I Want Your Sex, a remake of the 1978 mondo horror film Faces of Death, and a Romain Gavras movie called Sacrifice that also stars Yung Lean.

Title: Dave Coulier Battling Tongue Cancer After Beating Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma
Description:
By 

	Jon Blistein



	Former Full House star Dave Coulier is undergoing treatment for tongue cancer just under a year after beating non-Hodgkin lymphoma.


	Coulier revealed that he's now battling HPV-related oropharyngeal tongue cancer in a new interview with Today. “To go through chemotherapy and feel that relief of whoa, it's gone, and then to get a test that says, well, now you've got another kind of cancer … it is a shock to the system,” Coulier said.


	Oropharyngeal tongue cancer forms in the middle section of the throat, known as the oropharynx, per the American Cancer Society. The oropharynx includes parts of the tongue, the back part of the roof of the mouth, and the tonsils, all of which help with breathing, eating, swallowing, and talking. Saliva is produced in the oropharynx, too.


	Coulier said his doctors first noticed the new cancer during a routine PET scan check-up after he'd completed chemotherapy for his non-Hodgkin lymphoma. The comedian said something “flared on the scan” at the base of his tongue, so a biopsy was performed. 

	










			Popular on Rolling Stone		







	“It was very painful. It's like if you bit your tongue, but the pain just lasted every single day,” Coulier said.


	While the initial biopsy didn't show signs of cancer, the same spot had grown when Coulier returned for his next PET scan. Coulier went to an ear, nose, and throat oncologist for more testing, and after a CT scan, an MRI, and a second biopsy to remove an even larger part of his tongue, the results came back positive for cancer cells. 

	











	“[The doctors] said it's totally unrelated to my non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. This is a new cancer,” Coulier recalled. “I said, ‘Are you kidding me?'”


	Coulier's doctors told him the cancer could've stemmed from a long-dormant HPV virus that “activated and turned into a carcinoma.” But luckily, the comedian added, his doctors found the cancer early enough that was considered “very treatable.”


	“It's got a 90 percent curability rate,” Coulier said. “The doctor said the prognosis is good, but we're going to start radiation immediately.” 





	
		Trending Stories
	
	






	
	
		
					Buddy Guy: ‘I'm the Last Old Man Playing the Blues'		
	









	
	
		
					‘The Next Wave in the Opioid Crisis': A New Drug Stronger Than Fentanyl Is Taking Off		
	









	
	
		
					Evanescence to Embark on 2026 World Tour: ‘It Feels Like Everything at the Right Time'		
	









	
	
		
					Sean Ono Lennon Breaks Down His Oscar-Winning Short Film: ‘I Want to Make People Cry'		
	









	Coulier said his radiation treatments are less “aggressive” than chemo, there are still “side effects” like nausea and brain fog; he's also still contending with some residual pain from the biopsies. But Coulier and his doctors expect the cancer to be gone by the time he finishes radiation at the end of the year. 


	“My joke usually is … I'm doing really well for a guy with cancer,” Coulier quipped. 

We want to hear it. Send us a tip using our anonymous form.

Title: The Radicalization of Ziz Lasota: How an AI Doomer Became an Accused Cult Leader
Description:
Images within illsutration by Sonoma County Sheriff's Office; Adobe Stock; Getty Images	



							By 

	Tessa Stuart




Z
iz Lasota and Gwen Danielson had reached a stalemate. It was nighttime on the Caleb, the ancient steel-hulled tugboat where they had spent the last five months of 2017, anchored in the outer harbor of Pillar Point, 25 miles south of San Francisco. With their high cheekbones, dimpled chins, and penetrating gazes, the pair looked enough like siblings that strangers sometimes commented on their resemblance, but each could barely see the other in the pitch black that night, sitting on the floor of the boat's cramped control room.


	By her own account, Lasota was angry. Speaking into the dark, she remembers warning Danielson that “I would not at any point back down, and if [that] meant we were consigned to a runaway positive feedback loop of revenge, so be it … we might as well try to kill each other right then and there.” Then Lasota — who, at six foot two, stood five inches taller than Danielson — rose to her feet, silent, waiting for Danielson's reply.


	The rift in their relationship had started over money: It had cost more than expected to buy, fix up, and maintain the fleet of boats on which they hoped to eventually house a gang of brilliant programmers devoted to saving the world from an AI-engineered apocalypse. 

	










			Popular on Rolling Stone		







	On top of the upfront costs, they were paying berthing fees for three boats, not including the Caleb. Anchoring their tugboat in the outer harbor, where there was no fee, was meant to give them breathing room, but instead it teed up expensive clashes with the United States Coast Guard (who believed their boat, loaded with thousands of gallons of diesel fuel, posed a threat to the environment), and a nearby fuel dock operator (who accused them of illegally accessing his equipment in the middle of the night to pump contaminated bilge water off the boat). After they were discovered doing that, they were ordered to hire a tanker truck to remove any remaining “hazardous fluids” from the tug. (Lasota did not respond to interview requests, and lawyers representing her in pending criminal cases declined to comment for this story. Accounts of these events are drawn from Lasota's and Danielson's blogs, relevant court documents, and interviews.)

	











	
		Editor's picks

	The pair eventually became so desperate for money that they even, against their convictions as devout vegans, registered the Caleb for the purposes of ferrying crabbers out to sea to drop their traps for cash — a period Lasota referred to on her blog as “our attempt to be brutal consequentialists.”


	When Danielson first pitched Lasota on the idea of bringing other similarly brainy, ambitious, cash-poor members of the Bay Area's Rationalist community together to live on boats, it felt like a revelation. Both had moved to the notoriously expensive enclave to be part of an elite intellectual community that considered itself the last best hope to save humanity from total annihilation by superhuman artificial intelligence. By living on the water, they figured they could stay close to that community, without slaving away at a soul-sucking corporate tech job just to afford rent. 


	Danielson, who is bigender, was already living on a 30-foot Bermuda Sloop called the Islander when they met Lasota. Both navigating the early stages of their respective gender transitions, the pair bonded instantly, and Lasota was captivated with Danielson's vision for a “Rationalist Fleet.” “Maybe following Gwen's crazy idea would be an answer to the problem where whatever I expect to try, I just expected it will be too slow for me to save the world,” Lasota wrote on her blog.


	Together, with a third Rationalist, they toured a series of boats of varying levels of seaworthiness: a moldy motorboat for $1,000, a liveaboard “with no working motor but a pretty decent interior” hawked by a guy with a swastika tattoo, a Coast Guard Cutter turned fishing vessel named Pacific Hunter, and a sailboat with cabins for six called The Rapture. (“I joked if we bought it we could refresh that paint, then cross it out, and write, ‘The Singularity,'” Lasota later wrote, referring to the hypothetical point at which artificial intelligence will outstrip human intelligence, and become self-improving — an event, some believe, which will quickly lead to human extinction.)
